8689782839:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nHow to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\n

This is the second post in our series on web analytics for B2B websites, and builds on our previous post on the importance of establishing Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and Micro Conversions (MCs) to make meaningful improvements to your site. Today we’ll look at how to track those interactions within a web analytics tool with Event Tracking.

\n

If the thought of tracking KPIs and MCs sounds overwhelming, rest assured: all hope is not lost. In many cases all you need is to begin tracking Events.

\n

From a strictly technical standpoint, Events are ways visitors interact with your website without going to another HTML page on your website. For example, watching a video or clicking a link to another website are both instances of events: someone clicked something, and something happened that didn’t involve loading a new page. Setting up all your KPIs as Events can be incredibly useful when it’s time to report your analytical findings to leadership.

\n

Many people are unaware that this functionality is present in any analytics tool worth using. Siteimprove Analytics, Google Analytics, WebTrends, et all have the ability to track Events. Therefore, when evaluating tools for your organization it’s important to ask, “how are Events set up so I can effectively measure success on my website?” There is an opportunity for a whole separate post here on how to decide between free and paid tools, but for the sake of brevity I’ll limit my thoughts on that topic to a few sentences:

\n

Free tools and paid tools both cost money in different ways. If you are willing and able to pay with your time to learn the free tools, then you should use free tools. If you are unwilling and/or unable to pay with your time to learn the free tools then you should purchase a tool. There will always be a certain amount of work involved in effectively analyzing a website, and that time commitment grows if you decide to go the free route.

\n

Once you’ve decided what kind of tool is right for you, it’s time to get Event tracking set up! In most cases Events require a “Category,” “Action,” and “Label” so you can easily distinguish between different Events. It’s up to you (or you and your analytics provider) to determine the appropriate naming conventions for your Events. This is critical, as it will affect how you are able to use the data in your analysis. Due to the importance of this task I would like to look at each item on its own.

\n

Category

\n

The first part in naming an Event is placing it in a category. Video can be a category that encompasses all video on a website. Links can be a category for your Events that happen to be links. Audio can work for podcasts, etc. It’s best not to get too creative with your categories and just stick with common sense. The only reason to get creative is if you need to distinguish some sub-categories in order to better analyze your information.

\n

Here’s a quick example:

\n

Let’s say I’m a manufacturing company that builds different kinds of widgets based on two different types of customers, Mikes and Ikes. I have some PDF documents that outline the specifications of my widgets, and when those documents are downloaded that tells me there is an interest in potentially purchasing my widgets.  If the only category I had was “Documents” then I may need to do some extra analysis every time I needed to recommend website updates to my leadership. What I could do instead is have one category called “Mike Documents” and another called “Ike Documents.” Then I can look at my conversions at a glance based on the type of customer downloading the specs allowing me to determine a course of action with less effort.

\n

If you’re just getting started with this and don’t have access to a consultant, it might be wise to stick to more basic categories. If there is a case to be made for sub-categories, then go for it.

\n

Action

\n

Actions are very self-explanatory. This is the action that a user takes on an Event. For a video it could be “play,” for a link it could be “click,” for a document it could be “download.” We don’t need to get into much detail on these. Just call a spade a spade and you’ll be fine.

\n

Label

\n

The Label element is often the name of the Event being interacted with. The title of an individual document is a good label, the name of a video will work. This is another area that does not require much depth, just common sense. You simply need to be able to recognize individual Events within your categories and the Label is the way to do so.

\n

Once you have settled on the naming conventions for all your Events, you then need to follow the appropriate steps for your Analytics tool of choice in order to track them. If you’re a Siteimprove Analytics customer, that step is to contact our support team, who will guide you through the entire process. Otherwise, consult your tool’s support options and get down to brass tacks.

\n

You will then begin collecting the glorious information on how often people are taking action on your KPIs and MCs. This is progress! It is also just the second step in our journey, and there’s so much more value ahead. In our next installment we’ll take a look at the value of making Campaign Tracking a part of your outbound marketing efforts.

\n

Want more best practices for measuring your website’s success? Check out our report on the eight most deadly web analytics mistakes:

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689816109:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to figure out which How-To’s to write\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow to figure out which How-To’s to write\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\n
\n

The question is the answer

\n

Ok, that might sound stupid, but the trick to good How-To’s is ensuring that they answer actual questions from customers. One way to find some of these questions is to look at the questions users enter in the search engines to find your website. If a visitor asks a question in a search engine and ends up on a page of your website that doesn't answer that question directly, you have a chance to improve the user experience. If one person asked that question, chances are others will too. If you've written a solid answer, they could end up on your website. Who knows, they might even stick around and find some of your other content and services relevant - and before you know it they could be a new customer.

\n

Sieving data

\n

With hundreds or thousands of search terms used to enter your website, finding questions to answer may seem like finding a needle in a haystack. Filtering the search terms is your best friend here. In the screenshot below I’ve used a filter that only shows website visits where the user entered a search term with the word ‘how’ in it.


\n

The result is a very useful list of questions. Now you can find the questions you think are most relevant for your website and which include keywords you want to optimize your website for. Then it is up to you to write some quality answers as blog posts, FAQs, or whichever format best suits your website.

\n

Tracking performance

\n

The cool thing about a filter like this is that you can use the exact same filter to track the performance of your efforts.

\n

So when you’ve written a couple of How-To’s, you just have to look at your filtered analytics data, and then you’ll be able to see if traffic from the relevant search terms increase. Using the filter you’ll also be able to dive into behavior tracking, and see whether or not visitors stay on your website, and do what you want them to.

The possibilities with filters are endless. If you have any filter setups you want to share, or questions about filters, please fire away in the comments.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

9. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\n

It is a common misunderstanding that Portable Document Formats (PDFs) equal web inaccessibility but in fact a PDF is a document format that can be greatly accessible to many users.

\n

One question that many people ask is whether it is difficult to make accessible PDFs? The answer is no, it does not have to be. Here’s how you can easily improve the accessibility of your PDF’s.

\n

 

\n

Best practice for PDF accessibility

\n

The best and easiest way to create an accessible PDF is to take some specific steps in the authoring process, rather than trying to fix accessibility in a PDF post production with a remediation tool. For instance, you can take the following steps when creating a PDF in authoring tools such as MS Word and Adobe InDesign:

\n
    \n
  • Define the language the document is published in.
    • \n
  • Provide the document with a descriptive title.
    • \n
  • Use built in features within the authoring tool to define headings, paragraph text, lists, tables, alternative text for images etc. These are commonly known as tags.
    • \n
  • Ensure that the document has a proper reading order for those who use screen readers and similar assistive technologies.
    • \n
  • Create bookmarks – this is a good way for everyone to have an index / overview.
    • \n
  • Make sure you save as / export to PDF in a way that keeps tagging in the document.
    • \n
  • Check the PDF after conversion using a tool such as Siteimprove Accessibility.
    • \n
  • Make sure the security settings of the document allows for assistive technologies to extract text.
    • \n
\n

 

\n

Using remediation to help create accessible PDFs

\n

Any of the above steps can also be taken with a remediation tool should it not be possible to take them during authoring the original document, however, remediation is always more time consuming than having taken the steps originally during the authoring process. It is also important to note that if you need to make changes to the original document and create a new PDF, then you will lose steps you took with the remediation tool.

\n

So does this cover all possible PDF issues that may be present in a document? No, but it does address major PDF accessibility areas and will ensure that most users are able to access and read your PDFs. My personal mantra is “Better to be accessible to 90 % of your users than to 60 % of your users!”

\n

 

\n

Learn more about web accessible PDFs

\n

Would you like to learn more about how you can create, convert and check PDFs, through the process of document authoring tools such as MS Word, Adobe InDesign? Or learn more about how to use checking and certain remediation tools?

\n

Then don’t wait, download our latest guide: How to create accessible PDFs now!

\n

\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

A New Web Governance Roadmap

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/27/13 4:46 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Shane Diffily. The value of Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations, and online experience. Get it right and you'll have happy users and happy staff. But no online management system ever emerges fully formed. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team. Having worked with dozens of organizations, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases. Use the 'Web Governance Roadmap' described here to work out the distance you have covered on this journey - and what remains to be done.

\n

The framework outlined below provides a starting point for this conversation.

5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\nRead More\n

What's up with 'not provided'?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n

The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689816989:\n\n\n\n\n\nDon't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nDon't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School \n

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n8/20/13 10:36 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

\n
\n
\n

1. It’s Registration Week

\n

Students need information on classes, and fast. To help make your registration page accessible, especially with class offerings, ensure keyboard access for students or faculty who can’t use a mouse or similar devices. This may include users with limited to low vision or limited physical dexterity who want to get into the classes they need. By assigning an access key or keyboard shortcuts to links on the registration page you can provide all of the much needed information for users quickly and accessibly.

\n

2. It’s the beginning of the semester

\n

Many students are exploring your college’s website for the first time, so more users will be affected if it isn't accessible.

\n

"Accessibility is extremely important at all times, but especially during enrollment periods when user traffic is escalated.  We want everyone to have a positive experience while applying to our college, registering for classes and overall finding exactly what they need. We started using Siteimprove in April 2013, and the tool helped us identify and correct web accessibility issues in the critical areas on our website, and plan the new template with accessibility in mind.”  - Webmaster at Salt Lake Community College.

\n

Nowadays, Admissions Offices and Student Services Offices use a variety of digital mediums to reach out to students with slideshows, videos and much more. To help increase the accessibility of these visual marketing tools, alternative descriptions for images help screen readers and users decipher your campus. And for videos? Closed captioning and audio descriptions help students better understand what’s going on. These aids help give a more complete picture of your college’s branding efforts.

\n

3. Students are looking for financial aid

\n

Articles on the rising cost of tuition will naturally invite prospective students to visit the Financial Aid portion of your website. Colleges are required to utilize a Net Price Calculator* to assist students in understanding the value your college can provide. You’ll need to review yours for accessibility now! Net Price Calculators are notoriously inaccessible, causing further difficulty for prospective students.

\n

*Even though this tool is linked from a Federal Organization, it doesn’t automatically mean it’s accessible.  If it’s on YOUR website, it’s your liability/responsibility to ensure it is accessible.

\n

4. New applicants

\n

Of course, as the semester moves forward, you’ll be accepting new applicants for your college. But frustrations arise for disabled students who want to fill out your admissions application’s form fields. When form fields are not labeled for users, assistive technologies may either infer information or not provide any information to the user. Prospective students won’t know what is expected of them in any of the form’s fields. These road blocks can be solved by labeling the form fields, and will assist prospective students to fill out the application easily. 

\n

5. Staff Directories

\n

If prospective students have questions or want to visit the campus, make sure they’re able to check your Contact Us page easily. With tons of numbers in your directory, it’s hard to decipher the small font in the directory. Make sure it’s easy to enlarge the text by up to 200% and everyone will get to call the right office!

\n

These suggestions are not limited to the departments mentioned; each organization will have different requirements and focus areas. However, it’s a starting point and allows your team to be proactive about accessibility for smooth sailing this back to school season!

\n

Feel free to learn more about accessibility from our Web Accessibility expert Kevin Rydberg with his post: Kevin’s Top 10 Accessibility Tips. 

\n

Webinar: Introduction to Web Accessibility

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Just like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n9/5/12 3:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718697459:\n\n\n\n\n\nCarefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n

\nCarefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/3/12 4:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove series on maximizing the potential of a website redesign continues with today's post on the internal search function. We'll take a look at ideas on how your internal search can be used as a helping tool in the general design and testing of your website, as well as guidance on how to best design your search page.

\n
\n\n
\n

Use search statistics to get closer to your user's needs

\n

Your internal search can help you even before you start designing your website. This is the perfect time to take a closer look at what your users want by simply using your internal search statistics.

\n

You can benefit from your internal search terms when you decide about organizing your navigation menus and your website's general structure. Your most popular search terms tell you what your users are most interested in. Bring this information to the forefront of your website during a redesign. Make sure the information is visible on your home page, and use terms that users would use rather than sticking to another term that is often used within your organization.

\n

Use your internal search as a tool for testing migrated content

\n

Make your search solution run in a test environment. That way you can test whether new pages that are being migrated or added are shown correctly in your search results. Ask yourself:

\n
    \n
  • Is the title specific and unique for the page?
    • \n
  • Does the description help users decide which search result to pick?
    • \n
  • Are there any search results that come up in the results twice?   
    • \n
\n

During content migration, check search results every few days using the most popular search terms.

\n

Make sure you also find errors on parts of your website that you have been paying less attention to by searching for placeholder terms that should not be on the final site, such as:

\n
    \n
  • 'Test'
    • \n
  • 'No title'
    • \n
\n

These search terms might lead you to parts of your site that do not follow the general structure of the website.

\n

Designing your search page

\n

The trend in search page design leans towards simplicity. Filtering options, filed specific search boxes, and other extra functionality is only used rarely. My advice is that you only keep the most essential functions, and use the extra space for the search results.

\n

The search results are the main focus of the results page, so enrich these with useful and concise information. You can show photos of employees or contact info directly on the search page. Maybe there is a "buy'" or "download" link that can be displayed directly in the search result?

\n

Which content should your search solution cover?

\n

Ask yourself; which domains, sites and subsites do your organization use? Would any external sites be included in your search? Users are not aware of what and where content is placed on your sites. Let your search include content across domains, so you can maximize the help that is provided directly via your website.

\n

Your search statistics will guide you in finding out whether the content of a specific subsite should be integrated in the main site search or not. If the answers to your user's search queries are on a different domain of a different subsite, then include them in your mail search.

\n

You may also have information on your main domain that are not suitable to be made searchable from your global search function.  For instance, an archive of agendas and minutes is used by a specific user group. Most users have no need to access this information but the users who do may be more open towards using special functions, such as searching for a specific part of the document only or sorting results by date.

\n

When considering which types of pages should be in your main search there are three questions you should ask:

\n
    \n
  1. Do users search for the information on the pages? 
    2. \n
  2. Do the pages have a structure that makes it possible to integrate them well in the search? 
    3. \n
  3. Are the pages being searched for by a specific group of users only?
    4. \n
\n

If you decide to leave a part of your site out of the search and make it searchable in a separate search, remember to set up a quick link in your search that informs users about this. When using a separate search, it makes sense to address the needs of the user group that are especially interested in (e.g. minutes) by using advanced search functions since users with a special interest or knowledge use these options more often.

\n

Your search box should be prominent

\n

The search box should be at least as big as the main menu elements, and should either be placed in the top right area of the page or in the center part of the page. You can find some  inspiration for creating your perfect search box by clicking here.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718660159:\n\n\n\n\n\n3 Things you can do to improve your internal search\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\n3 Things you can do to improve your internal search\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/11/12 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

You may think you don’t need to do that? After all, you can find content without doing so. It is essential that you use the internal search regularly. Your search page transforms and looks different depending on which search term you use. Users on your website might view a search result page that you have never seen yourself.

\n
\n

Your search function might be in perfect shape, and not need any adjustments at all. If not, it is time to take control of your internal search function. Since the search function uses the content of the pages on your site the process mostly starts with improving the most important pages.

\n\n

Three things you can do to begin with:

\n
    \n
  • Build bridges between the terms that your users use and the terms on the website
    There is often a difference. What you call "bin collection" might be called "rubbish" by your users. One way of dealing with this is to integrate the terms used by your audience on the webpage.
    If a term should not be used on the website, the search engine can be set up to expand a search query for that term and search for the synonym present on the website as well.
    • \n
  • Give the search results relevant and specific titles
    The best place to do this is on the page itself - either in the title or the heading. If that is not possible you might be able to adjust the titles shown in your internal search tool.
    • \n
  • Make sure the most relevant pages are being ranked highest.
    Your search tool should be in line with the strategy for the website in general. If the goal for your website is for the users to use self service options, self service pages should be ranked highest, followed by pages with background information about the service. If your websites main goal is to promote the skills of the people working there, person profiles should of course be ranked highest. Sometimes there will be a need to refer to an external website or one your subsites that is relevant to the query at hand.
    In most cases minutes, forum posts and old news should be ranked low, so they only display if not other information is relevant for a query.
    • \n
\n

If your start working on these three points, a small effort will get you a long way!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689814679:\n\n\n\n\n\nSimple, yet lethal SEO no-no's\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n
\n

\nSimple, yet lethal SEO no-no's\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n


Forgetting to dot your I's and cross your T's

\n

Imagine if from this point onwards you decided never to add a subject to your emails again. Besides ticking off your boss and colleagues you'd probably also find out that you didn't get many answers. The same applies to forgetting to title your web pages or having the same title on duplicate pages. Without an engaging and descriptive title not only will Google struggle to find you, but your conversion rate will suffer. It's also important to remember that your title tag is what people are going to see when they are looking in search engines, bookmarks, or link to your page via social networks. If you're just using your company name or some other useless generic text then you should kick yourself, hard, right now.       

\n

Being too flashy for your own good

\n

While there may be occasions when flash is needed for websites, these occasions are few and far between. Designing parts or heaven forbid a whole website in flash is going to make it hard, if not impossible for search engines to read you. Flash also has the tendency to annoy users - as this website, aptly titled The World's Worst Website, so excellently demonstrates. If users feel like reaching for a stiff drink after being on your site something's going wrong.

\n

Using irrelevant keywords

\n

Knowing how to correctly use keywords is essential for good SEO. There's nothing worse than spending time and money on formulating a great site or blog to have no-one read it. Finding the right keywords for your business can be tricky, especially when you consider that many potential customers may misspell keywords or use different terminology from what you'd expect. To find the right keywords it's essential to use web diagnostic tools, as well as your own analytics to give you an insight into what terms are actually converting for you.

\n

Thinking Sex Appeal doesn't matter
"Sex appeal" and "URLs" may not exactly go together, but with evidence suggesting that long URLs act as a deterrent to users clicking rates, it is important to consider how your URLs appear. SEO expert and author Stephen Spencer found that short URLs are often clicked on twice as often as long ones. By comparison, long URLs can draw attention away from your search engine listing, helping to place the emphasis onto your competitors instead.   

\n

Linking like it's 1999

\n

Just as peeling paint can make a room look outdated so too can overly simple anchor text links. The soul crushingly common 'click here', 'read me' and 'buy me' links are for many people synonymous with outdated websites and outdated businesses. These ugly links needn't happen though as controlling your links is one of the many little things you can do to improve your SEO. So make sure that when you're linking you're using optimized anchor text.  

\n

Ana-what-ics?

\n

All too often people seem to think of SEO and Analytics as existing completely separately of each other. Clever people however will know that neither are anything without the other. Understanding how to do SEO better also requires understanding your users, their behavior, traffic hubs, preferred search engines and so forth. The more you know about your site and users, the better you'll be able to optimize content for searchers. 

If you've enjoyed reading this, do the kind thing and share it!  

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718662809:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhat is Web Accessibility?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWhat is Web Accessibility?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n\n

The truth is that web accessibility is made up of many things. And yes, uptime on a website fundamentally relates to whether your website is accessible for the users or not. There are also many parallels between optimizing your website for accessibility and SEO - because a search engine is also a type of user. Having the option of having things read aloud on the website is also a part of accessibility, but just a small part of the overall picture.

\n

So who defines what web accessibility is and where can this definition be found?

\n

The organization responsible for standardizing the internet is called the "W3C" (World Wide Web Consortium).  The W3C is a non-profit organization founded and headed by Tim Berners Lee, and they have a working group called WAI (Web Accessibility Initiative). WAI defines web accessibility and they compose guidelines on how to ensure good web accessibility.

\n

The standards set by W3C are globally recognized, so you can safely use these guidelines as a definition of the area. The set of guidelines that cover websites are called Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) and helps to ensure that as many web users as possible can use a website. The guidelines are formulated in such a way that by designing your website to comply, you also ensure a robustness that allows "user agents" (a fancy name for things like browsers and screen readers) to show and interpret your web pages.

\n

The WAI make a point of listening to comments and suggestions, taking them very seriously.

\n

As with most technical guideline documents, the structure and communication of the WCAG documents is unfortunately fairly complex.  It can take a lot of work to understand and interpret the meaning of the different criteria.

\n

To add to the complexity, in most web projects you will not be responsible for implementing all of the criteria. Usually, you'll need to pick out the areas that are relevant to your specific role.

\n

For developers, one set of criteria may be relevant to you, while a different set of criteria would be relevant to a CMS provider, or a web content editor, etc.

\n

In a series of future blog posts we will discuss these different sets of criteria.

\n

You can also look forward to a whitepaper on web accessibility which will be published on this website.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

CONFAB 2013 Minneapolis Roundup

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n6/12/13 2:33 AM\n

    \n

  • \n\n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week the lovely Kelsey and Dave from our US office were lucky enough to attend the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis conference. With so much packed into three days (and apparently some great food) they were kind enough to attend a plethora of talks, and take notes for those who were unable to attend. Below you’ll find five round-ups from some of the main Content Gurus were presented throughout the event – Enjoy!

\n
\nRead More\n

Get Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/3/13 2:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n

    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many people (ourselves included) are excitedly gearing up for the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis Conference kicking off today. A great event that spans three days, this year’s conference is completely sold out - but it doesn’t mean those of you who don’t have tickets need to miss out.

\n
\nRead More\n

The 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Previously we introduced the concept of ‘content strategy,’ and explained the three essential components that constitute its lifecycle – creation, publication, and governance. In this blog, will delve deeper into how Siteimprove can assist you during the first component: ‘creation.’

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

Simple, yet lethal SEO no-no's

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ensuring the last laugh isn't at your expense

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

Kevin Rydberg

\n
Kevin Rydberg is Siteimprove’s Senior eAccessibility Consultant, in the US office he is responsible for guiding and supporting businesses and organizations on their journeys to create accessible websites. Kevin has spoken across the United States at multiple conferences and events, most recently at the National Council for Marketing and Public Relations National Conference.
\n
\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Accessible Website Multimedia

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Cognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Semantic Markup and Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Q&A on the Basics of Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n2/11/14 9:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

We get a lot of questions on web accessibility here at Siteimprove, and want to take this opportunity to answer as many of them as we can. This may be more of a review for you seasoned accessibility folks, but there’s a growing demand for this introductory information as more web professionals recognize the importance of accessibility. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8692467149:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Quality Assurance, Check Website for Broken Links | Siteimprove\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\nLanguages\nUS\n
  • DE
    • \n
  • DK
    • \n
  • NL
    • \n
  • NO
    • \n

    • \n
  • UK
    • \n
\n
\nLogin\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Never miss a misspelling or broken link again.

\n

A broken link or misspelling can have a devastating effect on a visitor’s experience with a website, and therefore the image of the organization behind the website. Siteimprove Quality Assurance provides you with the tools to identify, locate and prioritize the repair of broken links and misspellings needed to protect your website’s credibility.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

But doesn’t my CMS do this?

\n

No. While a CMS system can help you gain a basic overview of your site, it is a very different tool from what Siteimprove offers. A Content Management System may help you quickly change content on your website but it cannot offer you that in-depth overview that helps you quickly identify and fix broken links and typos. But my CMSs checks for misspellings, doesn’t it? Most CMSs have a built-in spell check feature that allows the user to check content before publishing. For this feature to be effective, the user must run the spell check every time, and there is subsequently no guarantee that it is being done.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Improve your site’s usability, SEO and credibility

    \n

    With unique and simple features, Siteimprove Quality Assurance directs your attention where it’s needed most, correcting errors before they grow. Its intuitive user interface includes language and spelling management, broken link identification, a complete inventory overview of media files and documents, and access to custom reporting.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Manage Web Content Policies and Compliance

    \n

    Content Policy in Siteimprove Quality Assurance allows you to simply search for and review specific and unwanted content terms and numbers across multiple websites, such as phrases, symbols and dates so you can ensure company policies, compliance, and style guidelines can be met. Content Policy can also be used to search for old and redundant content, such as words and names or review branding irregularities which affect your users and reputation.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule and Customize Reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance custom reports are delivered directly to your inbox, with prioritized error lists directing your attention to where it’s needed most. Plus generate, schedule and customize unlimited report templates to suit you or your staff’s needs.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Access to Complete Inventory

    \n

    Get a comprehensive overview of media files, PDFs, and other documents across multiple websites. Find every instance of sensitive details like email addresses, phone numbers and social security numbers, plus utilize our simple diagrams which show which sites contain what media files, email addresses, and more.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove Customer Experience

\n

Online support services - Access product information, software updates and technical support resources online within the tool.

\n

Expert technical assistance - Siteimprove’s trained Customer Experience team is available to provide free expert advice and assistance for all your training and support needs.

\n

Full upgrade protection - Software upgrades and documentation are free, ensuring you stay current on the latest technical developments.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Six Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n6/20/13 2:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

When speaking about web governance (diagnosis, compliance and maintenance) of website quality assurance and accessibility, the common response is, our Content Management System (CMS) has a solution for this. However, this is the common misunderstanding.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week the lovely Kelsey and Dave from our US office were lucky enough to attend the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis conference. With so much packed into three days (and apparently some great food) they were kind enough to attend a plethora of talks, and take notes for those who were unable to attend. Below you’ll find five round-ups from some of the main Content Gurus were presented throughout the event – Enjoy!

Get Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n6/3/13 2:45 AM\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many people (ourselves included) are excitedly gearing up for the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis Conference kicking off today. A great event that spans three days, this year’s conference is completely sold out - but it doesn’t mean those of you who don’t have tickets need to miss out.

\n
\nRead More\n

Kevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

The 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n

The 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nRaising Digital Discrimination Awareness\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/21/13 3:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

\n

As part of our aim to further educate ourselves and our customers, we encouraged everyone  to try using their computers for just 30 minutes in a way that one with a disability may. This included options such as:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Using only the keyboard to navigate

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Zooming the browser to at least 200 %

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Using a read-aloud tool to access web information

    \n
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Using a tablet or smartphone to access web information
    • \n
\n

It proved to be an unmatchable learning experience for all involved, and many of our customers happily provided feedback about the experience, with three of the best published below:

\n

Marian Doucette, County of Huron, Web Architect, Canada:

\n

“It was frustrating! I definitely have new appreciation for accessibility and why it is so important. Two very popular news sites were selected for the test. One of the sites is known for being accessible and it was a breeze to navigate through. There were a few instances where I couldn't navigate as smoothly as I wished, but I was very impressed by the "skip to content" feature. The second site, which I'd assumed would be accessible, was very difficult to navigate and I quickly found myself in a never-ending keyboard loop. This GAAD experience will certainly kickstart our team's work towards making our website more accessible.”

\n

Stine Boeck, Furesø Municipality, Communication Consultant, Denmark:

\n

“I had thought, or maybe just hoped, that I wouldn’t have had as hard a time using the tab key to navigate as I did. I applied both restrictions when accessing …our own website… I am relieved to know that the two main entry points for citizens and business …is able to accommodate the 200% increase, though unfortunately on the individual pages the photos are indistinct, and the content difficult to read.”

\n

Rachel Daly, Preston City Council, Assistant Web Manager, UK

“I found the experience very eye opening. We have just carried out an accessibility audit on our website, so this area is something that is very much a key priority on our agenda at present.”

\n

 

\n

GAAD organizers Joe Devon and Jennison Asuncion also took the time to thank everyone for their enthusiastic support of what they think was an extremely successful second Global Accessibility Awareness Day.

\n

“…if you were introduced to digital accessibility for the first time because of GAAD, then we have all collectively met our goal…We can only imagine GAAD 2014 will be even bigger and better, and look forward to your participation” said Asuncion.

\n

As well as sharing our collective experiences, each office has also chosen to donate money towards a worthy charity in their respective area.

\n

Junior Blind of America

\n

The money raised in the US is being used to send five children to Camp Bloomfield for a week, where they will have the opportunity to develop their self-esteem, and independence in a natural and safe environment. Fully experiencing the joys of the great outdoors, children will be able to participate in activities such as horseback riding, archery and fishing.

\n
\n

Action for Blind People

\n

Our UK office has chosen to support the Bristol iCan Appeal, which is aiming to raise enough money to update the Action Technology Training Suite in Bristol, providing people with sight loss the chance to stay in employment and learn about accessible technology.

\n\n

Danish Blind Youth Society

\n

In Denmark the money raised will be put towards a special experience for visually impaired children during a summer canoeing trip, that aims to test their skills and boost their self-esteem. This weekend-long trip will include highlights such as a spit roast and harmonica playing around the campfire.

\n
\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Putting a Face on Accessibility Part II

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Kevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Raising Digital Discrimination Awareness

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/21/13 3:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/29/13 10:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/29/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web editor you are responsible for the content you publish on the website and it’s accessibility. Do you know how to support accessibility when you write texts and add images and links on a web page?

\n
\n
\n

This is the final blog post in a series of 3 that cover websites and accessibility with a role-based approach. This post is meant for web editors. The previous was intended for web designers and for web developers. I will give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get a head start by quality assuring your development site

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Integrate Accessibility in Your Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n11/21/12 3:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility isn’t something that is ensured solely through a website development project. To be successful, accessibility has to be a part of the overall web governance strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
