Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Accessible Website Multimedia

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Learning From Web Governance Anarchy In The U.K

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n9/2/14 9:59 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Have you ever heard the expression "democracy is a precious ambrosia carried around in the rusty bucket of human endeavor"?

\n

Well, rarely has that bucket been more rusty than when applied to governmental web governance.

\n

Experience shows that after lots of initial enthusiasm and conspicuous spending, many official sites quickly go into decline.

\n

The problem is that creating a website is now a box-ticking exercise - characterized by poorly understood goals and inadequate support.

\n

Thankfully, that is starting to change. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Food Pyramid

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8817739739:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nWhy Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n\n

Increased Site Traffic

\n

Not just any traffic, RELEVANT traffic. How do you know if it’s relevant traffic? Good question. Blogging adds unique pages to your website, and more unique pages will create more opportunities for you to show up in online searches.

\n

Typically, blogs focus on a specific topic that will resonate with users who are looking for specific answers, so over time you’ll be positioning your organization to answer any questions that your audience might have. The result? More opportunities to attract relevant traffic. However, this can be a double edged-sword…

\n

SEO

\n

While more pages and more traffic are a good thing, they’ll be worthless if you’re not producing high-quality content. As we discussed in a recent blog, the SEO landscape is evolving. Google’s search algorithm has been refined to reward the sites that produce the content its users are searching for, and penalize the sites that don’t.

\n

It won’t happen overnight, but if you’re playing by Google’s rules and putting out consistently high-quality content (the kind that is relevant to search terms and links to reputable sources), you’ll begin to see a bump in your organic search rankings.

\n

Social Media

\n

If you don’t have a robust social media strategy, or you’re always freaking out over what to post, your blog provides the perfect solution. Not only does it give you something relevant to share with your followers, it allows you to engage them in a deeper conversation, which stretches the reach and impact of your blog.

\n

It also gives your followers something to share, and then they’ll tell two friends, and they’ll tell two friends…

\n

Sales Leads/Conversions

\n

Blogs play an integral part in the sales conversion process. Whether they’re a customer’s initial entry point to your site or the final touch point before a conversion, your blogs can be used to drive readers through the appropriate stages of the conversion process.

\n

Every blog should have a relevant Call-to-Action (CTA) that encourages the reader to take the next step, whether it’s requesting a demo, downloading a document, or watching a video. This removes any barriers that might prevent a successful conversion.

\n

Thought Leadership

\n

The goal is for your organization to become synonymous with the product/service you provide. You want to be Kleenex®, not the company that makes facial tissues. By continuing to provide the information and guidance that your audience is looking for, you’ll demonstrate your knowledge of the topics that they find important and earn their trust.

\n

Over time, blogging will help establish your organization as a trusted industry resource, or “thought leader”, and the encourage people to seek you out first for answers to their questions.

\n

Quality Customer Interaction

\n

Blog interactions go beyond likes and shares, as they allow your readers to ask specific question about the topic you just covered. Your blog is the perfect medium for engaging your audience and demonstrating how your organization can help them solve a problem or provide a solution for their needs.

\n

 

\n

Developing a blog editorial calendar will help you map out key topics and be proactive about the content you’re providing. Don’t be afraid to ask your audience for feedback, because ultimately their needs should dictate what you’re blogging about.

\n

Need some help to get started in the right direction? Download our on-demand webinar for 5 helpful content governance tips.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9025215899:\n\n\n\n\n\nAccessible Website Multimedia\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nAccessible Website Multimedia\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n\n

WCAG time-based media criteria

\n

Guideline 1.2 Time-based Media:

\n

This guideline says to provide alternatives for time-based media; the purpose is to offer equal access to multimedia content. What is time-based media? Time-based media is simply a term that represents different formats of content that purposely changes or flows over time. Examples may include:

\n
    \n
  • Movies
    • \n
  • Audio clips
    • \n
  • Or animations
    • \n
\n

Let’s try to keep this simple. If you are using prerecorded or live media, (video or audio), you need to be sure there are transcripts, captions, or audio descriptions available.

\n
    \n
  • Offer a transcript or audio description for pre-recorded video content or pre-recorded audio (1.2.1, A)
    • \n
  • Provide captions for pre-recorded multimedia (1.2.2, A)
    • \n
  • Offer captions for live multimedia (1.2.4, AA)
    • \n
\n

“Wait a minute,” you say, “you mentioned animations…”

\n

I’m glad to see that you’re paying attention! Just be sure that your animated content has an acceptable text description.

\n

Pro tip 1: Captions and transcripts are good for searchability and SEO. Just sayin’.

\n

Keyboard traps

\n

What is a keyboard trap? A trap is when you are able to use the keyboard to navigate to a component or feature of a page, but then unable to navigate away from that feature.

\n

Media player accessibility

\n

A common example of a keyboard trap is typically a media player. Just be sure your users are able to navigate through or past the player with the keyboard.

\n

Pro tip 2: Be sure to design focus states so the keyboard user can see the active component on the screen.

\n

Video delivery systems

\n

YouTube

\n

Using YouTube for video delivery is a good idea for a variety of reasons. Not only is it a free service, but it also has global reach, and is incredibly reliable. YouTube has done a pretty good job of providing accessible accommodations, too. That said, there are a few problems to consider. Keyboard traps can be a problem with embedded players, so be careful when developing your video delivery system. Be sure to use the HTML5 version of the YouTube player instead of the Flash player; It’s much more accessible.

\n

With a quick Google search for YouTube and accessibility, you will see a variety of resources for screen reader users, captioning services, and accessible player APIs/scripts. With such a large community offering accessible solutions, you should be able to offer accessible YouTube videos on your website. If you are unsure if your videos are accessible, you will want to rely on a screen reader user to fully test your video player.

\n

Vimeo

\n

In January 2014, Vimeo updated its web-based video player with an HTML5 version, which greatly improved video delivery and accessibility. While there may still be room for improvement, the Vimeo player has good keyboard and screen reader support, and also supports captions and subtitles. You can consider Vimeo as a solid video delivery solution, especially as they continue to consider accessibility in future updates.

\n

HTML5

\n

Before HTML5, online videos could only be played using a plug-in like Flash. The <video> element of HTML5 offered a better, standard way to add video to a website. Cross-browser support and an almost unlimited library of scripts have allowed HTML5 to become the de facto method for online video. Mobile devices also offer excellent support for HTML5 <video>.

\n

 

\n

In this month’s web accessibility webinar, we’re going to discuss how to ensure that your multimedia content is accessible to people with disabilities by discussing how to meet WCAG guidelines, and then provide you with a few ways to begin improving your website’s multimedia delivery.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of Stuart Miles at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Siteimprove To Assist Minnesota Wild With Their Web Governance Goal

\n

MINNEAPOLIS, MN – November 19, 2014: Siteimprove announced today that they have partnered with the Minnesota Wild of the National Hockey League to use Siteimprove’s web governance suite, offered via Software as a Service (SaaS). Web governance is the practice of managing the quality and consistency of your online presence through organized systems, policies, and…

\n
\n

BY Callan Young

\n

20. Nov 2014

Siteimprove Releases New Trademark Monitoring Feature for Web Governance Suite

\n

Today, Siteimprove launched a new feature within their Web Governance Suite that enables users to monitor for consistent Trademark usage. This new feature allows users to ensure that names, copyrights, and trademarks are presented accurately according to organizational standards. Protecting intellectual property is essential in today’s constantly evolving digital marketplace, yet many organizations lack the…

\n
\n

BY Star Bazella

\n

2. Oct 2014

Siteimprove Promotes From Within, Names New VP of Customer Success

\n

Software as a service (SaaS) company, Siteimprove, has named Steve Hennigs as their new Vice President of Customer Success. Hennigs has been with Siteimprove since opening their U.S. office in 2007 and previously occupied the role of Senior Product Specialist. Hennigs will be heading up the newly created Customer Success Team, which will aim to…

\n
\n

BY Star Bazella

\n

8. Sep 2014

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028094089:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Governance for Non-Profits\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

Non-Profits

\n

Your website is the primary vehicle for sharing your organization’s values, stories, and goals. If visitors aren’t able to find what they’re looking for, or encounter errors, they won’t be able to make the generous donations needed for you to influence change and make a difference in people’s lives.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Non-Profits

\n

With Siteimprove, your team will be able to identify potential website roadblocks that are preventing you from achieving your goals, such as: broken links, misspellings, and accessibility concerns. We’ll also help you optimize your content for search engines and analyze how pages are performing, which will allow you to create more engaging content in the future.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check website accessibility issues WCAG 2.0

    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Simple HTML and CSS W3C web page validation

    \n

    Siteimprove Accessibility Issues and Guidelines also checks and evaluates your website’s HTML and CSS markup in conformance with W3C standards to quickly identify those portions of your website that need your attention. Code which is marked up in line with W3C is seen as good web practice and improves website accessibility and search engine visibility.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule and Customize Reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance custom reports are delivered directly to your inbox, with prioritized error lists directing your attention to where it’s needed most. Plus generate, schedule and customize unlimited report templates to suit you or your staff’s needs.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n

    \nFull Upgrade

    \n
    • \n

    \n\n

    \nUnlimited
    \nUsers

\n

Happy clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Every company with a large website should use Quality Assurance from Siteimprove. Nowadays, your website is your brick and mortar, so reputable content and accurate information is key to any brand. Siteimprove will streamline the process and easily point out any errors or inconsistencies.

    \n
    \nInternet Specialist at Saint Joseph Mercy Health System
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance, quite simply put is indispensable. I manage a higher ed website with thousands of pages and since incorporating Siteimprove into our maintenance schedule I have confidence that users will not find broken links or spelling errors, both which erode our credibility as an institution of higher learning. Whether a broken link is the result of a change from an external site we are linked to or a domino effect from something we have done elsewhere on the site, Siteimprove alerts us to the problem and we can address the issue quickly. The ability to segment and share the reports enables those closest to specific content to be involved in a productive and expedient way.

    \n
    \nAssistant Director of Communications at Cornell University
    \n
    \n
    \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9131522019:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Analytics Where To Begin \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

Web Analytics Where to Begin eBook

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

People love the Internet. A lot. In fact, 92% of online adults rely on search engines when looking for information.

\n

Web analytics provide you with a better understanding of how visitors are finding your website, how they interact with it, and how effectively your website is contributing to your business goals. This eBook will provide you with a better understanding of what web analytics are and how you can use them to achieve your business goals.

\n

This eBook will show you how to:

\n
    \n
  1. Identify Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and Micro Conversions (MCs)
    2. \n
  2. Utilize Events in order to track KPIs and MCs 
    3. \n
  3. Implement Campaign Tracking 
    4. \n
  4. Utilize Data Segmentation 
    5. \n
  5. Generate actionable reports 
    6. \n
\n

 

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9462815049:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

\nWeb Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n\n

Unfortunately, when it comes to web content, Google sets the objective standards for what qualifies as “high quality”. Once upon a time, SEO rankings were determined by easily exploitable metrics tied to keywords and page links, which led to far too many websites gaming the system by overloading pages with irrelevant keywords and misleading links in order to get more traffic and higher rankings. The problem here is that these webpages didn’t provide the information that they claimed, resulting in a bad experience for users and prompting Google to set their sights on punishing these types of sites.

\n

While elements like keywords and page links are still hugely important to your SEO rankings, and towards convincing readers that your website will provide them with what they’re looking for, the way in which Google analyzes and aggregates content is constantly evolving.

\n

What should your focus be?

\n

So, more content or more relevant content? Ideally you would be aiming for both, but your focus should be on putting out high-quality content that resonates with your audience.

\n

Some of you may have heard the term “click bait”. This refers to websites and online articles that attempt to get the most traffic to the page as possible, with little regard for how relevant or useful the information will be to readers. These flash-in-the-pan approaches will only hurt websites in the long run as they lead to high bounce rates and low engagement, which is a huge red flag to the search engine gods.

\n

High SEO rankings are not built overnight. They’re built over time by creating a constant and consistent flow of relevant, high quality content.

\n

Standing out from the crowd

\n

While playing by the rules is important, it’s only half the battle. If your content isn’t unique or offering readers something new and different, what incentive do they have to read it?

\n

Chew on this: 41% of consumers would end a brand relationship because of irrelevant content and promotions. If you’re flooding your readers with junk content, or the same nearly-plagiarized content as someone else, all you’re doing is giving them a reason to actively ignore you. You would be better suited not saying anything, than saying something just for the sake of saying something.

\n

At least twice a month, I receive snail mail from a well-known mortgage lender informing me that I could reduce my mortgage payment by up to $1,000 per year. Sounds like a super sweet deal, but I rent an apartment, so the content is all but wasted on me. In the event that I do purchase a home, the chances of me working with that particular company are highly unlikely because they’ve already lost my attention.

\n

Making real connections

\n

Consumers aren’t stupid. After decades of being exposed to every kind of marketing, advertising, and sales pitch known to man, they’ve learned to separate disingenuous schemes from authentic communication.

\n

You need to show your audience that you want to connect with them on a personal level by creating content that they feel will address their individual needs.

\n

Geoffrey James of Inc. Magazine describes the three levels of empathy that can help you connect with your audience.

\n

On-demand empathy

\n

This is the ability to sense what customers want. At a basic level, you understand your audience and what it is they’re looking for.

\n

Solution empathy

\n

This means going beyond understanding a customer's problem and figuring out how to address it. A potential customer usually has a problem that they know they need addressed. Your content at this level needs to directly address that problem and provide the solution to it.

\n

Transcendent empathy

\n

Perhaps the most powerful form of empathy, this means you’re able to create solutions for problems before customers even know that they have it. This is the true heart of real innovation and where you can create the most relevance to distance you from your competitors.

\n

The takeaway here should be this: when it comes to your web content, either tell the same story better, or tell a different story altogether. This might seem like common sense, but far too many organizations simply look at what works for others and then try to copy them. Don’t be afraid to do something different, it just might get you noticed.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

Corporate Responsibility at Siteimprove

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n4/25/12 11:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

At Siteimprove we work with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) as an essential part of the growth we experience in our three main markets in the UK, USA and in Denmark. A lot of initiatives have already been introduced, for instance we work hard to contribute to a higher degree of Web Accessibility on public and private websites. We wish to minimize our carbon footprint and offer our employees a sound and exciting working environment, in order to encourage employees to create new and even better Web Governance solutions for our customers.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nResponsibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/18/12 11:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Web professionals looking to improve their website accessibility using Siteimprove tools are finding that they have more issues in Quality Assurance, than they had in the former SiteCheck, but they are unsure of why.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Things you can do to improve your internal search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/11/12 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

You may think you don’t need to do that? After all, you can find content without doing so. It is essential that you use the internal search regularly. Your search page transforms and looks different depending on which search term you use. Users on your website might view a search result page that you have never seen yourself.

\n
\n

Your search function might be in perfect shape, and not need any adjustments at all. If not, it is time to take control of your internal search function. Since the search function uses the content of the pages on your site the process mostly starts with improving the most important pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

What can analytics do for your site performance and business goals?

\n

\n

Libraries

\n

Libraries have long been trusted institutions of knowledge and education. The wealth of literature, recordings, music, and videos provide patrons with a history that stretches back for generations. However, website errors can prevent viewers from accessing the information they seek.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Libraries

\n

With Siteimprove, your team will be able to identify potential website errors that are preventing your patrons from discovering the next great novel, such as: broken links, misspellings, and accessibility concerns. We’ll also help you optimize your content for search engines and analyze how pages are performing, which will allow you to create more engaging content in the future.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check website accessibility issues WCAG 2.0

    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check online PDF document accessibility errors

    \n

    As well as scanning web pages for WCAG 2.0 accessibility issues Siteimprove Accessibility also scans all of your site’s PDFs for detectable issues as part of WCAG 2.0 / ISO 14289-1:2012 / Matterhorn Protocol. This includes full document and single page element accessibility issues affecting usability, from missing headings and bookmarks to images without alternative text.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Happy clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance, quite simply put is indispensable. I manage a higher ed website with thousands of pages and since incorporating Siteimprove into our maintenance schedule I have confidence that users will not find broken links or spelling errors, both which erode our credibility as an institution of higher learning. Whether a broken link is the result of a change from an external site we are linked to or a domino effect from something we have done elsewhere on the site, Siteimprove alerts us to the problem and we can address the issue quickly. The ability to segment and share the reports enables those closest to specific content to be involved in a productive and expedient way.

    \n
    \nAssistant Director of Communications at Cornell University
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Our municipality and municipal officers have a passion for inclusive environments and removing barriers, and Siteimprove Accessibility helps us quickly determine exactly how to make that a reality. The ability to log in from any computer and for the product to connect directly to our web content management system saves us a bundle of time, and the way it breaks down web accessibility errors and notifications by priority compliance levels keeps our editors from getting overwhelmed.

    \n
    \nCoordinator of Customer Service at Town of Huntsville
    \n
    \n
    \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9577981539:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\nHow to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n\n

The way your website presents itself, and the way in which users interact with it, will have a significant impact on your organization’s ability to increase conversions and achieve its goals.

\n

Let’s take a look at some of the web design elements that can influence users and increase conversions.

\n

Navigation & Layout (User Experience)

\n

Think of the user experience of your website as how it “feels”, “functions”, and “flows”. Your site’s navigation needs to provide users with access to the content they need, in the fewest amount of steps possible.

\n

Poor website navigation has the same result as a driver encountering a “roundabout” for the first time. Common reactions include: “How did I get here?” “where am I going?" and, “how do I get out of here?"

\n

It goes without saying that your navigation should follow a logical progression, so the difficult question to answer is, which content will receive the most prominent placement within your site’s navigation?

\n

The answer can be found in a number of ways, but fastest and easiest way is to look at your analytics. Your analytics will reveal which pages your users visit most often, which ones receive the most interactions, and which ones aren’t quite cutting it. You won’t be able to please everyone all the time, so don’t even try. Instead, use this information to design your site’s navigation in a way that best serves your audience and your business needs.

\n

Aesthetics (User Interface)

\n

The user interface pertains to the interactive elements of a website- the text users will read, the buttons they will click, and the media they will view.

\n

Have you ever visited a website that was a little too “busy”? Instantly, you’re barraged by content, video, images, dozens of links, and endless choices. These types of sites often fail to present users with a clear path forward, like being dropped into the middle of a jungle with nothing but a canteen, a machete, and pat on the back for good luck.

\n

Humans are visual creatures. According to the Social Science Research Network, 65% of the population are visual learners. We like things that we think are pretty: pretty cars, pretty houses, pretty clothes, and pretty websites.

\n

A site can have great navigation, but if it looks “messy”, your users will never know it. They be too put off by the dated design, confusing color palette, or jumbled font treatments. Whether you base it on your business goals, or the information gleaned from your analytics data, the visual treatments of your website should drive users toward the most important content.

\n

Responsive Design

\n

Desktops, laptops, iPhones, iPads, Android phones, Android Tablets, Windows Phones, Windows Surface, overwhelmed yet? Think about how your website feels when it’s constantly forced to be zoomed, scrolled, pinched, and swiped across so many devices.

\n

Originally defined by Ethan Marcotte, Responsive Design is a byproduct of the web’s versatility and variety. With so many different devices, platforms, and mediums on which to view content, the digital world needed to free itself from the rigid constraints that carried over from print publications.

\n

Rather than forcing every device to find a way to house and navigate your website, usually through clunky scrolling and zooming, Responsive design allows your website to automatically adjust its size, layout, appearance, and functionality based on the user’s chosen device.

\n

Mobile Friendly

\n

Mobile use is growing faster than any other platform in the world, and will continue to do so as the technology behind it continues to evolve. If you don’t think your organization needs to prioritize its mobile strategy, think about this:

\n
    \n
  • Smartphone usage is expected to reach 2 billion by the end of 2015
    • \n
  • American’s spent 34 hours per month viewing the web/apps on their mobile devices in 2013- 7 hours more than they did on their computers
    • \n
  • Mobile devices account for 80% of China’s Internet traffic
    • \n
\n

Responsive design will help make your site mobile friendly by adjusting the layout to fit within the smaller sandbox, but that isn’t the whole story. The mobile environment requires a few extra considerations in order to provide users with the optimal experience:

\n

Touchscreen interfaces

\n

Save for a few stubborn holdouts, smartphones and tablets have fully embraced the touchscreen, which changes how users are able to interact with the “clickable” elements of your website. The usability of a website changes dramatically when the primary method of input changes from a mouse click to a finger tap.

\n

Take this into consideration when deciding where to place these elements, and how they are presented.

\n

File sizes and download speeds

\n

Remember that mobile users can be anywhere at any time, at that their Internet connection can range from “passable” to “oh my god, let’s go!” You can help them access your site faster by keeping its loading time down.

\n

Don’t bog down your mobile site with unnecessary elements, heavy visual treatments, or large images/videos.

\n

Vertical hierarchy

\n

Using a “single column” layout on your mobile site helps you cope with the limited space allotted by mobile devices. It also helps your content scale between different devices and viewing modes (portrait vs. landscape).

\n

This vertical, single column environment can sometimes lead to what’s known as the “endless scroll”. This happens when content that would normally stretch horizontally across a site is condensed into a slender space.

\n

You can combat this by adjusting the amount and length of content presented on your mobile site, or by implementing a collapsible navigation. A collapsible navigation will allow you to stack large amounts of content underneath drop-down menus that can be easily opened or closed.

\n

For more help on creating a usable, functional website, download our Foundations of a Website Redesign Webinar.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

Show me the money!

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/16/12 11:08 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

For most e-commerce websites it is relatively straight forward to put a monetary value on visitors, and therefore, it makes sense to put an effort into search engine optimization (SEO) to get more visitors. If you are running an information only website it might be a lot harder to find out how much a visit is worth.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 ways to improve your accessibility right now

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/9/12 11:11 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It can be difficult to know where to start if you have not implemented web accessibility before. Where do you begin and how do you finish? Some areas require time and a targeted effort whilst there are some ways in which you can improve your website accessibility right away, and at the same time conform with 3 important criteria in WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The added bonus of ensuring web accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Corporate Responsibility at Siteimprove

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n4/25/12 11:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

At Siteimprove we work with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) as an essential part of the growth we experience in our three main markets in the UK, USA and in Denmark. A lot of initiatives have already been introduced, for instance we work hard to contribute to a higher degree of Web Accessibility on public and private websites. We wish to minimize our carbon footprint and offer our employees a sound and exciting working environment, in order to encourage employees to create new and even better Web Governance solutions for our customers.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nResponsibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/18/12 11:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Web professionals looking to improve their website accessibility using Siteimprove tools are finding that they have more issues in Quality Assurance, than they had in the former SiteCheck, but they are unsure of why.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Things you can do to improve your internal search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/11/12 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

You may think you don’t need to do that? After all, you can find content without doing so. It is essential that you use the internal search regularly. Your search page transforms and looks different depending on which search term you use. Users on your website might view a search result page that you have never seen yourself.

\n
\n

Your search function might be in perfect shape, and not need any adjustments at all. If not, it is time to take control of your internal search function. Since the search function uses the content of the pages on your site the process mostly starts with improving the most important pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is web analytics important?

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/4/12 11:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

What can analytics do for your site performance and business goals?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Governance?

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/28/12 11:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Make your web presence an asset

\n
\n

Web governance is about ensuring full control over the organization's web presence by means of well thought out clear decision-making structures. For some, the organization's web presence is at best a necessary expense, and at worst a risk of legal actions, hacker attacks or the unwanted release of sensitive information. With sensible web governance you can turn the organization's web presence into a valuable asset.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Welcome to the new Siteimprove Blog

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n3/14/12 12:53 PM\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9780103539:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove's Webinar: 50 Shades of Gray. Is it accessible or not?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

\n
\n
\n

Webinar: 50 Shades of Gray. Is it accessible or not?

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Wednesday, January 28, 2015 at 1pm CDT

\n

Google “degrees of disability.” Go ahead; google it. I’ll wait. 112 million results? That’s a lot, isn’t it? From government agencies to higher education institutions, everyone has their own guide to help them determine levels of disability. What does this tell us? That it’s pretty challenging to determine or define a disability. What does this have to do with Web accessibility? When it comes to the WCAG 2.0 Guidelines, pretty much everything. 

\n

In January’s webinar, we’re going to take a look at why it’s so difficult to meet WCAG accessibility guidelines. There are certain guidelines that are pass/fail—black and white. But so many of the guidelines require a judgment call—gray areas. After all, they are called guidelines, aren’t they?

\n
\n

About the Host: Kevin Rydberg is Siteimprove’s Senior eAccessibility Consultant, in the US office he is responsible for guiding and supporting businesses and organizations on their journeys to create accessible websites. Kevin has spoken across the globe at multiple conferences and events, most recently in Stockholm for a web accessibility conference. 

\n

Optional Extra: Stick around after the webinar for a quick 15 min overview of our Web Governance Suite software.

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n

Use Web Governance to Secure a Strong Foundation for Your Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n11/28/12 3:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Who is in control of your internal search? If you want your search to work well you should include it in your web governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Integrate Accessibility in Your Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n11/21/12 3:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility isn’t something that is ensured solely through a website development project. To be successful, accessibility has to be a part of the overall web governance strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Dollars and Cents of Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n11/6/12 11:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

One of the biggest reasons we hear people say they don’t have a solid web governance strategy is because they lack the time and money required to implement it. What they often don’t realize is that time and money are exactly what a web governance strategy saves. In this post, we’ll be presenting a few examples from several other industries who have already spent the time and money to discover the savings offered by web governance.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

A New Web Governance Roadmap

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/27/13 4:46 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Shane Diffily. The value of Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations, and online experience. Get it right and you'll have happy users and happy staff. But no online management system ever emerges fully formed. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team. Having worked with dozens of organizations, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases. Use the 'Web Governance Roadmap' described here to work out the distance you have covered on this journey - and what remains to be done.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Winter Analytics Checklist for Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/12/13 10:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Last Wednesday, November 6th, 2013, Siteimprove was honored to be able to compete in the annual J.Boye conference ‘Web Idol’ competition. Held in Aarhus, Denmark, the conference is a series of international events that aim to bring web practitioners together in an informative environment that fosters relationships and encourages knowledge sharing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Six Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n6/20/13 2:30 AM\n

\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

When speaking about web governance (diagnosis, compliance and maintenance) of website quality assurance and accessibility, the common response is, our Content Management System (CMS) has a solution for this. However, this is the common misunderstanding.

\n

Last week the lovely Kelsey and Dave from our US office were lucky enough to attend the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis conference. Get Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013

\n

Many people (ourselves included) are excitedly gearing up for the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis Conference kicking off today. A great event that spans three days, this year’s conference is completely sold out - but it doesn’t mean those of you who don’t have tickets need to miss out.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792118319:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Redesign Checklist\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

\nWebsite Redesign Checklist\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n\n

With the right planning upfront, the entire website redesign process will go from big, scary monster, to big, cuddly, digital teddy-bear. Below are some key questions you should answer before you begin your redesign, and a few helpful tips on how to find them.

\n

Define the purpose of your website redesign

\n

“I just don’t like it” won't cut it. You need to identify measurable goals for your website. Where is the current site underperforming and preventing your organization from reaching its goals? How can you address those issues to remedy the situation?

\n

Some issues can be solved by improving the design or user experience. Other issues may require a more technical solution, such as improving the accessibility for disabled users.

\n

Once you’ve identified the problem, the solution won't be far away.

\n

Use data to drive decisions and planning

\n

Analytics data will tell you everything you need to know about how customers reach your site, and how they use it once they get there. Use this data to identify how and why your website isn’t performing well, which pages are getting the bulk of the traffic, and which ones are going unused.

\n

This will allow you to restructure your site in order to make it easier for users to accomplish their goals, instead of forcing them through a sales funnel that only accomplishes your goals. This will also allow you to create a plan for your website’s content, giving the user more of what they clearly want and need.

\n

Audit your existing content

\n

It’s important to know what you have, where it is, and what to do with it. Maybe a particular page should be moved up in the site hierarchy? Maybe you’re missing content on a critical page? By performing an audit of your existing pages and content, you’ll be able to identify areas that need improvement.

\n

Webpage Inventory Audit

\n

The easiest way to do this is to create a spreadsheet of every page on your website, list out the details and contents of the page, its purpose, and the target audience. From there, you can decide where the page should live on your site.

\n
    \n
  • List the URL, Page Title, and Navigation Title
    • \n
  • Determine the purpose of the page
    • \n
  • Identify the target audience
    • \n
\n

Content Audit

\n

On the same spreadsheet as the Webpage Inventory, list out the different types of content present on your site and how they contribute to your website’s goals.

\n
    \n
  • Articles
    • \n
  • Blogs
    • \n
  • Banner ads
    • \n
  • Forms
    • \n
  • Email newsletters
    • \n
  • Event calendars & registration pages
    • \n
  • Images, Audio, Video
    • \n
  • Social media sharing links [Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.]
    • \n
  • Staff directory etc.
    • \n
\n

The goal here is to get an understanding of how each piece of content contributes to the user experience and, ultimately, your business goals.

\n

Are you spending several hours managing certain content each week, but getting nothing in return? It might be time to reevaluate that content’s place and purpose on the site.

\n

Future Content Considerations

\n

Consider how your site will grow and evolve over time. This will allow you to implement a process that can adapt to your needs, rather than trying to force in a new change after it’s too late.

\n
    \n
  • Will you need an archive for news/blogs?
    • \n
  • Will you need to add pages/sections?
    • \n
  • Who will be responsible for managing new/old content?
    • \n
\n

Create a sitemap

\n

Your sitemap details the hierarchy and structure of the entire site. This document will have a simple look, but it’s crucial to the planning and design of your site.

\n

Think of your sitemap like a family tree. It will detail the order and organization of your pages, and how they’re related to one another.

\n

\n

Create wireframes

\n

Wireframes are similar to a sitemap, in that they are a rough guide to show you how the website will look. However, wireframes are used to show a rough layout of how certain kinds of webpages will look. Don’t worry, you don’t need to create one for every single webpage, just one template for each type of page.

\n
    \n
  • Homepage
    • \n
  • Products
    • \n
  • Blog
    • \n
  • About
    • \n
\n

The wireframe should outline the different areas where content will live on those types of pages.

\n

\n

Establish a web style guide

\n

The web style guide is a set of rules that governs how your site uses/displays things like:

\n
    \n
  • Navigation titles & heading tags
    • \n
  • Paragraphs, lists, and tables
    • \n
  • Links (active, hover, and visited states)
    • \n
  • Images & Videos
    • \n
  • Background images and watermarks
    • \n
  • Sidebars
    • \n
\n

This shouldn’t be confused with your brand guidelines, which dictate how your brand assets are to be used/displayed. The web style guide pertains specifically to how your website is structured and how it presents content.

\n

It’s a lot to consider, but in the long run, having a solid plan in place before you start the process of actually creating your new website will save you time, headaches, and money.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\nAsk Us Anything Preview\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n\n

For those who are just hearing about it, Ask Us Anything brought 5 of our resident Web Governance, Web Accessibility, and Content Marketing experts together in order to answer questions submitted by our customers.

\n

Below are some of the questions we weren't able to answer during the live recording, but you can download the full recording here.

\n

OK, now here's your free knowledge for the day:

\n

1. Can we pull reports in the Siteimprove tool for just our Admissions webpages and have them sent only to selected users, instead of everyone?

\n

 Heather Orfe - Technical Support and Training Manager

\n

"This setup is easily obtainable through the settings within the ‘Access & Reports’ portion of a user’s profile shown in the image below.

\n

\n

In this portion of the user setup, you can assign the user with access to the tool and QA reports – once you have these changes, you’ll then have additional options to provide the user access and reports to any group you currently have setup. Select the page group(s) the user is responsible for, then select ‘Group access only’ in the upper right corner.

\n

This parameter specifies the users’ settings to only the pages in the group(s) you’ve assigned them to. Without this distinction, a user would have access to the entire sites performance, with an option to manually select into their group."

\n

2. What are the most common accessibility concerns for web users?

\n

 Kevin Rydberg - Siteimprove Senior eAccessibility Consultant

\n

"A few of the questions I get regularly include, 'What are the requirements or regulations I need to follow?' and 'Where do I start?' One of the first things to consider is that accessible coding is a process, not a singular task. These coding practices need to become part of your daily workflow and in time, will feel like a natural part of the development process.

\n

The best places to start, in order to determine the requirements for your website's accessibility, are the WCAG website and Section 508 website, which outline some of the most common accessibility challenges, regulations, and how to address them.

\n

You can also read some of my Web Accessibility blogs for more specific details on how to make your website accessible for all users."

\n

3. I need to review analytics for a section of my website, but cannot use the Page Title or URL for Grouping, what do I do?

\n

 Steve Hennigs - Siteimprove Vice President of Customer Success

\n

"There is an option where Siteimprove can look for a unique piece of HTML on your page, for example if you have a BreadCrumb present, and use that to put common pages together in groups. This does require some interaction with the Siteimprove support team for the initial set up but once that is complete you are able to add groups through the Siteimprove UI.

\n

Just contact our support team and they'd be happy to help get you started."

\n

4. How do I identify if a website redesign is necessary?

\n

 Star Bazella - Siteimprove Director of Marketing

\n

"First, consider the business goal of your website. The design of your website must serve the right purpose, and help you achieve a clearly identified goal, or set of goals. Here are some questions you should answer to determine if a website redesign is necessary.

\n
    \n
  • Which areas of your site are performing well, underperforming, or failing completely? Basically, what problems or issues are you trying to fix with a new site?
    • \n
  • What do you want visitors to know about your company/organization?
    • \n
  • What do you want visitors to do when they visit the site?
    • \n
  • How can you attract visitors and convert them into leads?
    • \n
  • What does success of your website look like?
    • \n
\n

Remember that success does not mean the same thing for all pages or types of visitors. Consider how returning visitors might have different needs from new visitors, or how visitors from an email might have different needs than visitors from organic search. Think about the goals of individual pages and subdirectories, and how they might differ."

\n
\n

Download the full Ask Us Anything recording here. 

\n

 

\n

  \n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Accessible Website Multimedia

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Cognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Semantic Markup and Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ask Us Anything Preview

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

    \n
    • \n

    \n

\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n
\nRead More\n
