Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

Mie Elmkvist Jensen

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Tell users about your cookies

\n

\nPosted by\nMie Elmkvist Jensen\n

\n

\n5/23/12 11:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Online privacy is a global hot-button, with lawmakers pressuring organizations to more tightly regulate the information they gather from visitors. The European Union recently enacted legislation dubbed the "cookie directive" has organizations scrambling to make their websites compliant. Many organizations in the US may not realize that they need to comply with these rules if they intend to operate a website in the EU. For those of you who don't run multiple sites, these simple tips may give you a head start preparing for future US legislation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792126669:\n\n\n\n\n\nWant to understand accessibility? Participate!\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nWant to understand accessibility? Participate!\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n\n
\n

On May 9th the first Global Accessibility Awareness Day was held. I see this as a great opportunity to make an extra effort to spread the knowledge and understanding of digital accessibility. I started at home by encouraging my colleagues here at Siteimprove to take part in the event.

\n

They were all encouraged to work on the web for a half hour to an hour in one of the following ways:

\n
    \n
  • Put the computer mouse away and navigate solely by the use of the keyboard
    • \n
  • Disable style sheets in the browser and browse web pages this way
    • \n
  • Enlarge content in the browser 200 % as a minimum and even better 400 %, 600 % or 800 %
    • \n
\n

And why is this a good exercise you might ask? It is a good exercise because many who are familiar with accessibility guidelines do not have the insight of why the rules are there. Even though you might at some point have been informed about the impact it has on your work, one might quickly forget to integrate accessibility in one's working procedure. At Siteimprove, accessibility is an integrated part of every day's work but it is still a good exercise helping the attitude towards the area to have a basic understanding of WHY it is important and not just considered another set of rules one has to comply with.

\n

Many computer users cannot use a computer mouse, and have to navigate from the keyboard alone. It can be a big problem for them if some elements on a web page can only be accessed with a computer mouse. Some people use screen reader software that renders the web content to the user in one long sequence. The experience can be compared to viewing a page without design (style sheets) for a visual user. Because of this, it's important to screen reader users that content be rendered in a meaningful sequence.

Another group often experiencing accessibility issues are the visually impaired, who need to enlarge content on a web page in order to be able to read the text. It is a common problem for these users that elements or text on the webpage disappears or overlaps when the text is enlarged. Because of these different user scenarios containing accessibility issues, three of the criteria for web accessibility cover the following: All content on a web page must be accessible from the keyboard alone (criteria 2.1.1). The content of a web page must be presented in a meaningful sequence programmatically (criteria 1.3.2) and the size of text can be resized and as a minimum be enlarged 200 % (criteria 1.4.4). 

\n

Many of my colleagues were happy to take up the challenge and considered it to be a great learning experience. Most of them reported that after just 10-20 minutes they were profoundly frustrated about things like reading a web page with text enlarged: "it was simply a pain having to scroll so much just to accomplish any little thing. What a hassle!". Others were frustrated with encountering functionalities on a web page that could not be accessed with the keyboard: "I wish more web editors took on these type of challenges in order to understand how disabled people may experience the web".

\n

In general the feedback was that this type of exercise helps the understanding of the challenges that accessibility problems entail for users: "Seriously though, this is hard and my appreciation for those that are physically impaired has risen tremendously!" 

\n

So, I would like to encourage everyone who works with web to do the following: Choose one of the criteria in the web accessibility guidelines and simulate a user scenario that enables you to have a better understanding of why accessibility guidelines are important. You can start with one of the scenarios recommended by the people behind Global Accessibility Awareness Day.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\nCelebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n\n
\n

The man who started and heads this growing company, Morten Ebbesen, remembers his early forays into the business world. ”Early on I knew that entrepreneurship would be a big part of my identity, and when I started Siteimprove it was just a couple of programmers and myself in a small Copenhagen office with a big dream.” Since then Siteimprove has gone from strength to strength, and it is now the world’s number one provider of web governance tools and solutions.

With more than 1500 accounts worldwide, and over 30,000 users, Siteimprove has played an integral role in revolutionizing the way the industry thinks about web governance. Previously an unfamiliar term, web governance is now the key benchmark for every website in the world.

With a plethora of customers across numerous verticals including healthcare, government, 
manufacturing, finance, higher education and law, Siteimprove provides cleverly simple website management tools for some of the world’s best-known companies and organizations including US Bank, Mayo Clinic, London School of Economics, John Hopkins University, Harvard Web Publishing and British Library.

Performing over 64 million website checks a week may seem daunting but for Ebbesen this is just the start of a long and successful future.

“Having succeeded as much as we have in the past 10 years a lot of people may expect us to slow down but I have no plans of that. With an ever changing market I feel certain that Siteimprove will only continue to grow and mature, and that this will correlate into significant growth, not only logistically but also financially.” 

As Siteimprove heads into it’s next decade the focus is strongly on innovation. New product developments are already in the pipeline, as are a range of new and exciting innovations that are guaranteed to again change the way the industry views hot topics such as accessibility. With the world at it’s feet the future looks very bright for this uniquely entrepreneurial company.

\n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

Winter Analytics Checklist for Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Don't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n8/20/13 10:36 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792140039:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nSiteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/12/13 10:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Last Wednesday, November 6th, 2013, Siteimprove was honored to be able to compete in the annual J.Boye conference ‘Web Idol’ competition. Held in Aarhus, Denmark, the conference is a series of international events that aim to bring web practitioners together in an informative environment that fosters relationships and encourages knowledge sharing.

\n

Throughout the day, we participated in a number of workshops and sessions held by renowned international speakers, and in the evening, we competed against seven other vendors for the title of ‘Web Idol’. The competition was a lot of fun, although the pressure was on! Vendors were given only six minutes to present a case study and explain how their product had assisted in solving a web problem. Based on the American Idol structure, vendors were advised to have fun and make the audience laugh while showing off their products in a simple and informative way.

\n

Each presentation was judged on five criteria; Relevance and importance of the business problem being addressed, innovation, originality, ease of application and practicality. Competing against us were Content Management System (CMS) vendors Zengenti and Magnolia, SharePoint provider Webtop, customer management firm SDL and Software as a Service (SaaS) firm Active Standards.

\n

While the competition was tough, at the end of the day the crowd of highly experienced web professionals voted and we were crowned the winner! Our presentation was praised for its originality, and for easily highlighting how the Confederation of Danish Industry (DI) has benefited greatly from using Siteimprove Quality Assurance. With more than 10,000 members, 30 thousand plus pages and more than 250 editors that add content on a daily basis, we were able to show the audience the measurable improvement Siteimprove can offer its customers. 

As part of our attendance, we also produced a free web study that looked at the average number of misspellings, broken links, Search Engine Optimization issues and accessibility issues on 50 of last year’s participant’s websites, including Swarovski, MAN Diesel, IBM, PayPal and others.

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792150599:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n\n
\n

Stop Dropping and Rolling

\n

The first step is often the hardest, and this is no exception: if you want to be proactive you absolutely, positively have to stop putting out fires.

\n

I know, I know.  This isn’t a novel suggestion you’ve never thought of before, it’s probably the first thing you’d wish for if you stumbled upon a magic lamp.  Here’s another thing you probably already know: There’s a good chance the only way you’ll ever be able to do it is by taking a stand with your boss and asking him/her to hold off on bringing you little details like they’re emergencies.

\n

If you can’t get a moment’s peace to plan ahead, you’ll be stuck fighting fires for the rest of your life. That’s bad for you and bad for your organization, because you’re way less effective at doing the things they’ve hired you to do when you’re running around with your hair on fire.

\n

There are lots of great articles on the web about how to approach your boss, so I won’t go into too much detail on the specifics of how to do it. Make sure you have a private discussion with your boss about how to reach a mutual goal, instead of confronting them in a meeting. Plan what you’re going to say ahead of time, and make sure you speak in terms that matter to them, keeping the company as the focus. How much more of the company’s objectives could you accomplish if you weren’t constantly putting out fires? How can you work together to lessen the flow of emergencies to make that happen?

\n

It’s a scary conversation to initiate, but if you want to be proactive it’s 100% necessary.

\n

Make Yourself Flame Retardant

\n

Now that you’ve talked to your boss and reached an agreement on stopping or slowing the fires, it’s time to start working ahead. If you don’t have written goals and objectives for your website, you need to sit down with your boss and make them. Then, define your Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and build goals based on them.

\n

The most important thing to consider when making metrics for your website is mapping them back to business goals. A metric that doesn’t match company or department goals will be easily overridden by the next “emergency” and won’t protect you from firefighting in the future.

\n

Once you’ve set your goals and KPIs, all your tasks should explicitly support them.  Keep an updated list of all your tasks, which goals they support, and what priority level they are. The next time your boss comes to you with another fire to put out, show them your task list and what you’re currently working on, and ask them to prioritize the fire. If your goals and KPIs are clearly tied to the company/department’s goals and you explain that putting out this fire will delay your other objectives, chances are they’ll rethink the importance level of the new task. This is especially true if you’ve already had a productive discussion about the detriment to your productivity posed by firefighting.

\n

However, some level of firefighting will always be a part of every job, which is why this section is titled “Make Yourself Flame Retardant” instead of “Make Yourself Fireproof.” Be flexible to the needs of your boss, and understand that they may be coming to you due to pressure from the people above them. They might appreciate the assistance so much, they’ll let you do your job!

\n

Get tips and best practices for your next website redesign project:

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Roles and responsibilities in Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n10/10/12 3:59 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Do all employees in your organization know what their role is, and what is expected of them? Do employees know who to ask questions outside their own work area? Do you know what every employee in your web team does?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Awards

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n6/13/12 10:50 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

\n\n\n\n

\n
\n

It's official: we're fun.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Map your current web governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/30/12 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many organizations talk about Web Governance, but what is it – and why should you care? Simply put, Web Governance is a general term for the system of policies and guidelines you use for making decisions about your organization’s web presence. This system may be ill-defined and poorly organized, but it’s important to realize that you already have Web Governance. Thus, it makes sense to start working with Web Governance by mapping your organization’s current state of Web Governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Tell users about your cookies

\n

\nPosted by\nMie Elmkvist Jensen\n

\n

\n5/23/12 11:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Online privacy is a global hot-button, with lawmakers pressuring organizations to more tightly regulate the information they gather from visitors. The European Union recently enacted legislation dubbed the "cookie directive" has organizations scrambling to make their websites compliant. Many organizations in the US may not realize that they need to comply with these rules if they intend to operate a website in the EU. For those of you who don't run multiple sites, these simple tips may give you a head start preparing for future US legislation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Governance?

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/28/12 11:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Make your web presence an asset

\n
\n

Web governance is about ensuring full control over the organization's web presence by means of well thought out clear decision-making structures. For some, the organization's web presence is at best a necessary expense, and at worst a risk of legal actions, hacker attacks or the unwanted release of sensitive information. With sensible web governance you can turn the organization's web presence into a valuable asset.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792127409:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nWebsite Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n


Knowledge without action

\n


Talking after the conference, Jacob was satisfied with the participation from the attendees. “Our booth was very popular and I got to show many of the things that people have a hard time imagining until they have seen a review of their website made by a blind person.”

\n

According to Jacob, an increasing number of people are aware of website accessibility. “Most of the people who asked me to review their site were aware of website accessibility and knew that their site had flaws, but could not pinpoint exactly where to make improvements. They were all surprised when I went through their site with them and took a closer look at what worked and what didn’t.”  Indeed, in a survey Siteimprove carried out at the conference, 93% of web developers and managers who responded indicated they were aware of it  - yet many still don’t know how to develop an accessible website.

Jacob reports commonly experiencing problems when surfing the Internet, exemplifying that without concrete actions,  awareness of website accessibility means very little.

\n

Typical website accessibility issues

\n

Interestingly, several issues Jacob came across are much more common than others, such as missing ALT-Text Tags on images and media, applets, or other non-text web content.

\n

“It’s a huge help for me if forms are labeled and if there are heading elements, especially on larger websites. The biggest problem for me is often when there is no possibility of fast navigation, then all features of the page must be loaded, which can take forever. Preferably, everything should be able to be activated from the keyboard. The reason you cannot activate everything on the website from the keyboard is not due to technical reasons but ignorance from the web developers of the site. They are probably unaware that full web accessibility is a necessary feature for many users,” Jacob said.

\n

Web accessibility budgets and priorities

\n

“Budgets and priorities play a large role when it comes to whether a website is accessible or not,” said Jacob. While he hasn’t noted a remarkable difference in accessibility based on whether a site is public or privately owned, he has noted that perceptions to change may differ.

\n

“Private sites aren’t always willing to change if you tell them that something is inaccessible, whereas public sites often make website accessibility changes because they have a certain obligation towards all kinds of users. The budgets seem to play a bigger role for private sites as well: they are typically only driven to change things if they can make a profit.”

\n

Why website accessibility?

\n

For companies and organizations considering whether to invest in making their site handicap-accessible, it usually comes down to one question: “Will it make a difference to our bottom line?” The answer is a resounding “YES!” Often considered something that only benefits a small group of users online, making a website accessible is not only the right thing to do but also the  smart thing. Having an accessible site leads to better rankings in search engines and generally supports SEO efforts. Not a bad side effect!

While many mistakenly believe that it is both costly and difficult to develop an accessible site, it doesn’t need to be, and getting help from an accessibility expert before developing or re-designing a site is a great place to start.

\n

Download our on-demand webinar "Introduction to Web Accessibility"

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792133019:\n\n\n\n\n\nGetting Started With Web Analytics\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nGetting Started With Web Analytics\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/9/13 10:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In this post, you'll find a brief walkthrough of how to begin using the basic features of an analytics program. We will be using Siteimprove Analytics as our example, however the suggestions made should carry over to any program.

\n
\n\n
\n

The Dashboard

\n

The dashboard is the central hub of any web analytics program, and displays summaries of your most important data all in one place.  Here's what the dashboard looks like in Siteimprove Analytics:

\n

 

\n

1. Filters

\n

Filters tailor all the data you see displayed in the program.  They can be customized to filter out traffic from within your organization, filter by times and dates, or even filter by where visitors came from.

\n

2. Unique Visitors

\n

The number of different visitors to your website in the selected period. If someone visits your site, leaves and then comes back it will only count as one unique visit.
Important things to note: this doesn't necessarily reflect an accurate picture of the number of people who visited, because most people today have multiple devices (computers, tablets, smartphones). For example: if someone visits your website from their work computer during the workday, and then later visits your website again from their personal laptop at home, there's no way for your analytics program to know that this is in fact the same person using different devices.  So "Unique Visitors" is really more a measurement of the number of devices that have visited your website. There are other ways that this number might be affected by visitor behavior like clearing their browser's cookies, but for the purpose of brevity we won't get into that here.

\n

3. Visits

\n

This is the total number of times that anyone visited your site, whether it was for the first time or the hundredth time. If someone visits your site, leaves and then comes back again, it will count as two visits.
Important things to note: there is a timeout limit of 30 minutes on each visit. If someone views your website and then leaves it up on their computer while they go watch TV for a while, when they come back and view another page, it will show up as a second visit.

\n

4. Page Views

\n

A count of how many times a page or page group has been viewed in the selected time period. If a visitor hits your homepage, that's one page view. If they then go on to your "About Us" section, that's a another page view. 

\n

5. Bounce Rate

\n

The bounce rate is calculated by dividing the number of single-page visits (in which a visitor only viewed one page before exiting the website) by the total number of visits by the number of visits.
While it has become a staple of most analytics program dashboards, the Bounce Rate really isn't the best way for beginners to measure their website's performance.
Say your website has a bounce rate of 65%, what does that tell you? Are visitors bouncing because they found what they wanted, or because they didn't find what they wanted?  If people commonly visit your homepage to find hours of operation, your address, phone number, etc. they will most likely bounce if they find what they're looking for on your page (many sites have this information in the footer). So in that case, your analytics program reports a bounce even though your users found exactly what they were looking for.

\n

6. Most Popular Pages

\n

Your website's most popular pages are listed in order of page views and bounce rate.  These web pages are typically the ones that are the closest to your home page, requiring the fewest clicks to get there.  However, if you see pages deep in your website at the top of this list, you may want to consider moving them closer to the homepage to make them easier to find. To see the full list of pages in order of popularity, click the "View more" button.

\n

7. Referrers

\n

This graph displays the different types of ways people are finding your website online. As you can see in the screenshot above, "Direct Traffic" usually makes up the majority of your referrals. "Direct Traffic" refers to people who directly typed your URL into their browser, rather than clicking a link or doing a search.

\n

"Search Engines" is fairly self-explanatory, showing how many of your website's visitors found you through searches on Google, Bing, Yahoo!, etc.

\n

"External Referrers" shows people who found your website by clicking a link somewhere else on the internet.  If Jimbo's Jumbo Texas Shrimp blog posts a link to your website telling his readers that you sell the best shrimp cocktail sauce, anyone who follows that link to your website will show up under your "External Referrers" category.

\n

8. External Search Terms

\n

Since search engines make up a sizeable chunk of total website traffic on most websites, it's valuable to see which searches people are using to find you. Usually the top search terms are all variations of your company or product name, which isn't all that helpful.  However in Siteimprove Analytics, you can filter out all variations of your company, product or any other criteria you like to help you focus on what's really important.

\n

Have questions about analytics?  Leave a comment below and our Analytics expert will get back to you ASAP!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nA Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n8/13/13 10:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

\n
\n
\n

Check out Fishkin's video on link building vs. content marketing here.

\n

The purpose of a law firm website

\n

Before we can discuss why this is the correct choice we need to consider why a corporate law firm has a digital presence at all: websites, attorney blogs, social media, client alerts and other publications are all created with the goal of building client trust, nurturing the relationship and positioning the firm/attorney as a leader in their field. The occasional client may find and hire a firm for corporate work based on a Google search, but this is not a recipe for ongoing success.

\n

Most General Counsel and other potential corporate clients will explore a firm’s digital presence after receiving a positive referral from someone they trust, or after having met one of the firm’s attorneys in person. This is why the majority of keywords used to find a corporate law firm website are either a version of the firm’s name or that of one of the attorneys.

\n

Once on the firm’s website, clients expect to see content that is relevant to them, well thought out, trustworthy, and above all else valuable. If they succeed in finding this content, the chances increase that they will seek out the firm for additional information, subscribe to their newsletter, follow the firm’s social media channels, etc. If the content continues to be valuable, they will consider hiring the firm.

There are varieties of other factors that will determine if a firm is ultimately hired, but if the content has aided their search then the digital presence has done its job.

\n

Link building and legal marketing

\n

If you watch Fishkin’s video, you will see it is very clear that link building doesn’t lead to the outcome described above. Many firms are doing content marketing now and just calling it by a different name. The problem however is that when firms, attorneys and marketers hear the phrase “SEO” they immediately think of link building, believing it to be a magic bullet that instantly delivers business.

\n

Link building is fine for consumer products and even for many consumer law firms, but just won’t cut it for successful long-term business relationships built on trust. Creating trustworthy and valuable content on a consistent basis is the approach attorneys need to be successful online.

\n

I am not the first person to advocate this by a long shot (see: O’Keefe, Kevin) and I certainly won’t be the last. The issue many firms struggle with is getting their attorneys to create enough content. My assumption, and please let me know via the comments if I am mistaken, is that attorneys expect immediate business from these efforts, and when that doesn’t happen they abandon the approach.

\n

Managing client expectations 

\n

It is reasonable and necessary to expect results, but one must consider people’s hiring characteristics when creating expectations. Expectations based on the common scenario presented earlier in this post will result in a more realistic chance of a firm’s digital marketing activities meeting and exceeding goals.

\n

The process Fishkin lays out for Content Marketing seems to make sense for a firm to follow. Identify your audience, find out where they and their influences go online, create valuable content for them and repeat. If you do this and follow some basic SEO practices (good on-page SEO, utilizing Authorship, etc.) then links will build themselves naturally. More importantly a firm will foster trust with their clients, build stronger client relationships and showcase themselves as leaders in the industry - which was the point of all this to begin with. 

\n

About Steve Hennigs

\n

Steve Hennigs is an accomplished speaker, author, and analytics & SEO consultant serving the legal marketing field for more than three years. He aims to help law firms ensure they follow SEO and web analytic best practices, as the best way to understand their websites better and achieve a higher return on investment for their digital marketing efforts.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\nRaising Digital Discrimination Awareness\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/21/13 3:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

\n

As part of our aim to further educate ourselves and our customers, we encouraged everyone  to try using their computers for just 30 minutes in a way that one with a disability may. This included options such as:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Using only the keyboard to navigate

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Zooming the browser to at least 200 %

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Using a read-aloud tool to access web information

    \n
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Using a tablet or smartphone to access web information
    • \n
\n

It proved to be an unmatchable learning experience for all involved, and many of our customers happily provided feedback about the experience, with three of the best published below:

\n

Marian Doucette, County of Huron, Web Architect, Canada:

\n

“It was frustrating! I definitely have new appreciation for accessibility and why it is so important. Two very popular news sites were selected for the test. One of the sites is known for being accessible and it was a breeze to navigate through. There were a few instances where I couldn't navigate as smoothly as I wished, but I was very impressed by the "skip to content" feature. The second site, which I'd assumed would be accessible, was very difficult to navigate and I quickly found myself in a never-ending keyboard loop. This GAAD experience will certainly kickstart our team's work towards making our website more accessible.”

\n

Stine Boeck, Furesø Municipality, Communication Consultant, Denmark:

\n

“I had thought, or maybe just hoped, that I wouldn’t have had as hard a time using the tab key to navigate as I did. I applied both restrictions when accessing …our own website… I am relieved to know that the two main entry points for citizens and business …is able to accommodate the 200% increase, though unfortunately on the individual pages the photos are indistinct, and the content difficult to read.”

\n

Rachel Daly, Preston City Council, Assistant Web Manager, UK

“I found the experience very eye opening. We have just carried out an accessibility audit on our website, so this area is something that is very much a key priority on our agenda at present.”

\n

 

\n

GAAD organizers Joe Devon and Jennison Asuncion also took the time to thank everyone for their enthusiastic support of what they think was an extremely successful second Global Accessibility Awareness Day.

\n

“…if you were introduced to digital accessibility for the first time because of GAAD, then we have all collectively met our goal…We can only imagine GAAD 2014 will be even bigger and better, and look forward to your participation” said Asuncion.

\n

As well as sharing our collective experiences, each office has also chosen to donate money towards a worthy charity in their respective area.

\n

Junior Blind of America

\n

The money raised in the US is being used to send five children to Camp Bloomfield for a week, where they will have the opportunity to develop their self-esteem, and independence in a natural and safe environment. Fully experiencing the joys of the great outdoors, children will be able to participate in activities such as horseback riding, archery and fishing.

\n
\n

Action for Blind People

\n

Our UK office has chosen to support the Bristol iCan Appeal, which is aiming to raise enough money to update the Action Technology Training Suite in Bristol, providing people with sight loss the chance to stay in employment and learn about accessible technology.

\n\n

Danish Blind Youth Society

\n

In Denmark the money raised will be put towards a special experience for visually impaired children during a summer canoeing trip, that aims to test their skills and boost their self-esteem. This weekend-long trip will include highlights such as a spit roast and harmonica playing around the campfire.

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792142959:\n\n\n\n\n\nJust like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n

\nJust like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n9/5/12 3:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

\n
\n\n
\n

As a company with offices in multiple countries and continents, we at Siteimprove feel it's important to be involved with our communities wherever we are.

\n

We recently partnered with Go ON Gold, a national web accessibility campaign in the United Kingdom. After partnering with them, we were shocked to learn that 43% of disabled people in the UK have never been online.

\n

Therefore, this post aims to raise awareness of the barriers that people with disabilities and learning difficulties face when using websites. Fundamentally, it explores how those responsible for websites can use specific web based tools to tackle and prevent accessibility issues. Before I start, it should be noted that online accessibility is an extensive subject, so I recommend reading previous Siteimprove accessibility posts and our recent white paper  'How to ensure website accessibility'.

\n

Why use a tool to improve your website's accessibility?

\n

Ideally, a website's accessibility should be addressed when planning and designing a website, however this is often not the case. There is commonly no plan in place to monitor future accessibility issues of a website; those that comply with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).

\n

In short, using a tool speeds up the process by automatically detecting and identifying underlying accessibility issues, and any new problems that may emerge on your website as a result of new guidelines, human error or inexperience of accessibility. It also makes otherwise complex, extensive and time consuming manual tasks much easier by being able to:

\n
    \n
  • Have a large library of WCAG success criterion to perform checks from
    • \n
  • Automatically detect both site specific and page specific issues
    • \n
  • Cover all conformance levels
    • \n
  • Show progress status and historical views
    • \n
  • Highlight priority pages with most issues
    • \n
  • Provide detailed and extractable reports
    • \n
\n

Some common detectable and fixable issues

\n

As an experiment, I ran some tests using Siteimprove's Quality Assurance and Accessibility toolcrawling 2000 pages on two leading Paralympic websites, which would be fair to assume are top runners in having good accessibility.

\n

In regards to complying with WCAG, there were a number of Level A issues (minimum conformance level) which were picked up. For instance, missing alt text, which is a  1.1.1 success criterion of WCAG. This means that screen readers and blind people would not be able to understand what the image was, as there was no descriptive text. This was found on important 1st level pages, for images such as booking tickets, and dates for Paralympic reunions. To address this issue, appropriate alt text might be, 'Buy your Paralympic tickets by clicking here' and 'Click here to see dates for Paralympic reunions'.

\n

Another Level A issue apparent on a homepage was link text not passing  WCAG 2.4.4. This showed several 'Read More' links. Unfortunately this link text duplication is actually a hindrance to screen readers as they provide no description of what the link destination is. A solution to this would be to provide a description of that URL within the main copy, e.g "There were lots of interesting tactics during the football match, Great Britain vs China". Where "Great Britain vs China" is a link.

\n

Furthermore, tests recorded 283 broken links and 13 misspellings on one website, and the other had 874 broken links and 82 misspellings. Common misspellings, and punctuation errors included:

\n
    \n
  • 'Competiton'
    • \n
  • 'paralympics'
    • \n
  • 'bejing'
    • \n
  • 'olympic'
    • \n
  • 'defense'
    • \n
  • 'mens'
    • \n
  • 'diveristy'
    • \n
\n

These are basic principles and web standards that can be easily detected using a tool, as well as fixed by using CMS integration.

\n

One thing to consider when using any tool is that they should not be used for training purposes, and without having a good knowledge or understanding of accessibility. Accessibility is an extensive topic, which should be researched thoroughly before making any decision for improvement.

\n

Building a legacy for your website's users

\n

If you are planning, redesigning or maintaining a website, then my advice is that you stop to think about how many users you are excluding if not ensuring website accessibility; what implication it is having on your organization or business? Are you taking unnecessary calls or inbound enquiries? Is your SEO affected by your syntax missing structured headings, alt text, or not passing HTML validation? Does it affect usability?

\n

In next week's blog,  Helene Nørgaard Bech, Siteimprove's Senior Accessibility consultant will be writing about accessibility for mobile platforms, which is certainly worth looking out for.

\n

As usual, post your comments below.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nThe 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n

 

\n

Content Safeguarding is Essential

\n

The publication stage can often seem like the simplest stage of the content strategy lifecycle, yet it is also the time when credibility and reputation threats are at their highest. Therefore, it’s essential that organizations undertake two reviews, the initial and the comprehensive. An ideal way to streamline these processes with the use of cleverly simple web management tools.

\n

The Initial Review

\n

This stage should determine the overall quality of information and from a content strategy perspective should involve ensuring that published content will be compliant with international web standards. With estimates that 20% of the population has some form of disability that makes accessing the web difficult, it is essential that your site that is accessible to all. This may seem like a monster task, but with help from the Siteimprove Accessibility tool it needn’t be.  

\n

Easy to use, with helpful instruction materials, its ‘summary’ feature provides a clear overview of all accessibility issues affecting your site, as well as highlighting which errors most require your attention. By reviewing your contents accessibility, you’ll be sure to have content that is more inclusive, will better fulfill all users’ expectations, and that can even assist in improving your SEO efforts.    

\n

\n

 

\n

The Comprehensive Review

\n

An in-depth and informational review will help ensure the accuracy and completeness of information. This should involve checking to make sure that there’s no spelling mistakes anywhere on your site, that all links work as intended, and that every piece of content is where it should be. With Siteimprove Quality Assurance ensuring your website’s credibility is protected needn’t be a logistical nightmare.

\n

 

\n

Finding every single spelling mistake on your website is like finding a needle in a haystack, especially if your site has many pages, or is in more than one language. Siteimprove Quality Assurance is designed to help make this task manageable, with it’s extensive dictionary that’ll find all misspellings, and a clever editing feature that can both allow certain words, and flag those others that are deemed inappropriate.

\n

 

\n

Intuitive crawlers are also an essential part of this tool, as they check every link on every single page of your site so you don't have to. As part of this review process, our tools can also help you ensure all site content, such as email addresses, telephone numbers, videos and PDFs, is correct and where it needs to be.

\n

While the publishing stage has the potential to derail your larger content strategy it can be made much easier with the use of web management tools, and as such any organization attempting to enforce or renew their strategy should consider these options.

\n

Stay tuned for next week’ final installment in the Siteimprove Content Strategy Blog Series as we discuss tips and tricks for successful content governance.  

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792160629:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n\n

What is Net Neutrality?

\n

According to Tim Wu, Professor at Columbia Law School and pioneer of the Net Neutrality terminology, “The idea is that a maximally useful public information network aspires to treat all content, sites, and platforms equally.”

\n

Essentially, it’s the idea that all legal content, and content sources, are viewed as equals by the companies whom we pay to provide us with Internet access. So, cat videos on YouTube and entire seasons of Toddlers & Tiaras on Netflix are given the same merit as an E-Book on Aeronautical Energy Efficiency from the NASA blog.

\n

Net Neutrality is the only thing preventing Internet Service Providers from dictating which companies, and which content, will receive preferential treatment.

\n

Why do Internet Providers Want it Changed?

\n

The argument being made by Internet Service Providers (ISPs) is that sites which are responsible for higher traffic and larger amounts of data downloads (streaming sites like YouTube and Netflix) should be required to pay more in order for users to access their content.

\n

This idea of creating a “fast lane” is not attainable in regards to a globally shared broadband internet, as increasing speeds for some, means decreasing speeds for others. Think of it as a highway where one lane is reserved entirely for those who are able to afford the fee for using it. The rest of the users would be relegated to the other lanes, causing more congestion.

\n

How Will This Impact Businesses and Consumers?

\n

One would think that ISPs should have the right to charge certain content providers more money if they are responsible for higher traffic and data downloads. The issue becomes one of equal access, as companies with large budgets can afford to pay a fee for higher speeds, smaller companies and startups would find themselves at a severe disadvantage. The outcome would see consumers being forced to use these “first class” sites as a result of the faster speeds, while the slower sites would become “second class” and see a steep drop in traffic and service quality.

\n

What would happen if a small, non-profit company were providing crucial information to millions of people, but their ISP decided to charge them a large fee in order to maintain their service quality?

\n

Another concern is Internet Service Providers being allowed to “double-dip” by charging companies an extra fee on top of the one they already charge to consumers. This would effectively punish smaller companies for not being able to compete with the large wallets of their competitors and leave consumers with little choice as to which sites they are able to use effectively. Further concern would be raised if the new fees for content providers led to an increase in pricing for services like Netflix, Amazon Prime, or even Google.

\n

Another area of contention is that ISPs would essentially be allowed to favor their own content by providing it at faster speeds, while “throttling” the speeds allotted to their competitors. For example, Comcast could boost speeds towards their own On-Demand services, while decreasing speeds for Netflix or Amazon Prime.

\n

What Can You Do?

\n

The topic of Net Neutrality is not a new one. ISPs have been clamoring for the ability to charge premium fees to large companies for more than a decade, and the current political implications stretch back as far as 2007, when then Presidential candidate Barack Obama promised to uphold the principals of Net Neutrality and refrain from appointing an FCC Chairman who would seek to circumvent the principles of Net Neutrality.

\n

On May 20, 2014, the FCC will propose its new Net Neutrality rules to congress, and while the debate is likely to continue for some time, there are a few ways in which you can help to preserve the ideals of an open Internet.

\n

Politely contact your state legislator before May 20, 2014 and share your thoughts.

\n

Politely contact FCC Chairman, Tom Wheeler before May 20, 2014 and share your thoughts.

\n

Politely share your thoughts with the FCC before May 20, 2014.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What We Learned At Confab Central 2014

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Roles & Responsibilities on Website Teams

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Cost of Your Website's Broken Links

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Take a Load Off: Reduce Your Workload Through Website Automation

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

\n
\n
\n

The Cost of Your Website's Broken Links

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n
\nRead More\n

What We Learned At Confab Central 2014

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n
\nRead More\n
